content.definition: Compression of the brachial plexus in the thoracic outlet, causing upper extremity pain, paresthesias, and weakness. Neurogenic TOS is the most common form (95% of TOS cases) but is often controversial due to lack of objective findings in many patients.

true_neurogenic_tos.definition: Objective neurologic findings with EMG abnormalities

disputed_neurogenic_tos.definition: Symptoms suggestive of TOS without objective findings
features: Normal physical examination or subtle findings

compression_sites: Interscalene triangle (between anterior and middle scalene)

symptoms: Pain in neck, shoulder, arm (most common)
provocative_tests: Roos test (3 minutes of elevated arm exercise)

diagnosis.clinical: Based on symptoms and provocative tests
electrodiagnostic: Often normal in disputed neurogenic TOS
diagnostic_blocks: Scalene muscle block with local anesthetic

factors: Workers compensation claims have worse outcomes

learning_objectives: Distinguish true vs disputed neurogenic TOS
Understand the importance of patient selection for surgery
clinical_pearls: Neurogenic TOS is 95% of TOS but most is 'disputed' without objective findings
TRUE neurogenic TOS: cervical rib + Gilliatt-Sumner hand + EMG changes
Positive scalene block predicts surgical success
Conservative therapy first for disputed TOS (3-6 months)
